results.title: Beyond our vision
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Developing image”.
The need for accurate recording through photographs is examined, in both the past and the present. The program explores Western survey photography, including an original Western survey album used to persuade Congress to make Yellowstone National Park, Eadweard Muybridge’s stop-action photography and Landsat satellite imagery. Photography can now provide viewers insight into places, objects and events, beyond their personal experience.

results.title: The Family album
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Developing image”.
Highlights the most frequent subject of photographers past and present, the family portrait. Provides a history of family portraiture, including daguerreotypes and wet-plate photography, as well as the development of Kodak roll-film cameras. Includes interviews with leading contemporary photographers who specialise in family portraiture.

results.title: Solutions to images
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Developing image”.
This program contains a technical survey of the main photographic processes from the daguerreotype to the Kodak#1. Explores an antique tintype gallery and shows a wet-collodion negative made during the American Civil War.

results.title: The Camera image: more than a record
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Developing image”.
This program examines the pre-history of photography, discussing the concepts of visual perspective, mechanical devices leading to the invention of the camera, and the cultural needs that generated the invention of photography. The special qualities of the camera and its artistic capabilities are discussed.

results.title: Olympic glory: the golden years
results.creator_credit: Denis Phelan, James Murray, Big Fights Olympic Library, Golden Years and Video Sports
results.brief_description: This series captures the golden years of Olympic competition where heroes like Dawn Fraser, Betty Cuthbert, Jesse Owens and Mark Spitz became legends of the Olympic spirit. Rare archival footage, narrated by Norman May, makes this a must for sports history lovers.

results.title: Heroes, heartbreaks and hilarities
results.creator_credit: Denis Phelan, James Murray, Big Fights Olympic Library and Golden Years
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Olympic glory: the golden years”.
The Olympic tradition has not only fostered great sporting champions, it has created immortal images of heroic proportions. Legends such as Johnny Weissmuller, Emil Zatopek, Ron Clarke and many others have become household names, their personalities taking over where sporting achievement leaves off. This is their story - a story of heroes and heartbreak - where athletes are pushed to breaking point and beyond in the struggle for Olympic glory. It is also a look at the lighter side of the Olympic personality and the truth behind the iron-clad determination athletes must present in the heat of competition! Production is based on the “Big Fights Olympic Library”.

results.title: The Melbourne Games
results.creator_credit: Denis Phelan, James Murray, Golden Years and Video Sports
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Olympic glory: the golden years”.
Live through the unforgettable action for the first time the Olympic Flame blazed in the Southern Hemisphere. This program captures the momentous highs and lows Australians were able to savour first hand. It includes footage of the remarkable first, second and third places captured by Australian swimmers in the women’s 100m final, headed by the fabulous Dawn Fraser. The explosive confrontation between Hungarian and Russian water polo teams, less than three weeks after the Russian invasion. The pride of Betty Cuthbert’s glorious wins in the 100m, 200m and 4 x 100m relay races. Plus all the local magic of a youthful nation hosting the world’s premiere sporting competition. Narrated by Norman May.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Denis Phelan, James Murray, Golden Years and Video Sports

results.title: Swimming and diving
results.creator_credit: Denis Phelan, James Murray, Big Fights Olympic Library, Golden Years and UP Sports
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Olympic glory: the golden years”.
A history of the modern Olympic Games which utilises archival media footage to illustrate some of the heroic achievements of Olympic swimmers and divers. This tape includes footage; the springboard diving win of Pat McCormick in 1956; the Gold Medal wins of Shane Gould, Dawn Fraser and Murray Rose.

results.title: The World at war. - Volume 6.
results.creator_credit: Martin Smith, Ted Childs and Thames Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The World at war”.
Part 11: “Red Star” The story of Russia’s massive lonely war with its 20,000,000 military and civilian casualties. A Leningrad housewife who survived the 890 day siege from September 1941, until January 1944 appears in this program. She agrees she was lucky to survive. In her city of three million inhabitants 200,000 people were killed by German shells, a further 630,000 died of cold or starvation. Incredibly the Russians survived and went on to rout the Germans. Part 12: “Whirlwind” The blitz on Britain brings strident public demand for revenge bombing but by the end of 1941 Britain’s force of 700 aircraft is being eaten into by the demands of the North Africa and Atlantic battles. The arrival of Arthur “Bomber” Harris to take charge of Bomber Command heralds a new attitude. Harris is very much in favour of revenge - “They have sowed the wind and now shall reap the whirlwind”, he proclaims publicly. More important, he believes that bombing can, on its own, defeat Germany.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martin Smith, Ted Childs and Thames Television
